Here is the simplified text for a B1 level learner:

Losing your luggage at the airport can be very frustrating. You might have to wear the same clothes for hours or even days until the airline finds your bag. This can be especially bad if you're in a different climate or far from home. Airlines don't usually say how many bags they lose, but it's a common problem. Even the best airlines make mistakes sometimes.

The airline's baggage system has a few flaws. They have to check you in early so that your bag can get to the plane on time. They also have to allow some extra time for your bag to get from one plane to another. But sometimes flights are delayed because of security checks or air traffic. This can cause problems with your bag.

Human error or accidents can also happen. For example, the label might get torn off. This can happen more often at big airports where many bags are being handled. Even good airports like Amsterdam or Singapore can have problems sometimes.

To avoid losing your luggage, try to take a direct flight and check in early. If you have to change planes, try to fly with the same airline. Give yourself extra time by taking an earlier flight and make sure your bag is clearly labeled with your home and holiday addresses, and the flight numbers. If your bag still goes missing, go to the baggage hall and fill out a report before leaving the airport.

Note: I kept the main points and facts of the original text, but simplified the language and sentence structure to make it easier for a B1 level learner to understand. I also removed some technical terms and jargon to make it more accessible.<|eot_id|>

Kingfishers are popular among wildlife photographers because they are beautiful and can be easily watched from a hiding spot. Charlie's first hiding spot was an old blanket, and he took his first good picture of a kingfisher after four years of trying. Kingfishers became his passion, and he spent all his free time near a stream with many kingfishers. However, he had to miss school, which affected his grades. Despite this, his love for kingfishers got noticed, and he started working as an advisor for a nature magazine. He now works as a freelance wildlife film cameraman and wants to make the perfect kingfisher film. He wants to show the beauty of the bird through pictures, without using words. Here is a simplified version of the text for a B1 learner:

**Theme Parks in Britain**

If you're thinking of taking your children to a theme park, there are many to choose from in Britain. We asked five families to try out the best ones. Here are their experiences:

**Fun Island**

We went to Fun Island with our three-year-old child. We thought it might not be as exciting as a big theme park in the US, but we were surprised. The park has many rides for younger children, so our child didn't feel left out. The kids loved the Crocodile Ride and the Giant Wheel. There's even a special ride for very young children that was a big hit. For older children, there are scarier rides like Splash Out, where you jump into a pool! We only didn't like that the park didn't have much atmosphere and the scenery was not very nice. But the staff were very helpful and the park was clean and well-organized.

**Wonderland**

We went to Wonderland with our family, including a three-year-old. We didn't know what to expect, but our child loved it. He enjoyed the Mountain Train and Little Land, where there were small replicas of famous buildings at his level. The older children liked the ferris wheel and driving toy cars on a real road. We spent six hours there and were glad there were places to rest. The park is nicely designed, and the staff are very helpful and friendly.

**Adventure World**

We spent seven hours at Adventure World and still had a lot to see. The children loved the Big Top Circus, which had a great trapeze act. They also enjoyed the Terror Line, although they were a bit scared. Their favorite ride was Running River, where you think you'll get wet, but you don't. For younger children, Toy Land is a lot of fun. The park is well-designed, so even waiting in line isn't boring. It's very clean, and the staff are great.

**The Great Park**

We visited The Great Park, but it only opened until 5 pm. This park is great for younger children because the rides aren't too scary. Even I, who is a scaredy-cat, had fun. We all loved Exotic Travels, a boat ride that starts slowly and then becomes exciting. We waited in line for half an hour for Lightning River, and it was over before we knew it! If you're brave, the Big Leap looks great, but I wouldn't go on it.

**Fantasy World**

Fantasy World has many rides, including Europe's tallest rollercoaster. Our child thought it was the most scary ride, but another child thought the Hanger, where you hang upside-down 30 meters high, was even scarier! There are many rides for older children, and some for younger ones too. We thought the staff were a bit mixed - some were great with young children, but not all were friendly. You need a full day to enjoy Fantasy World.<|eot_id|>

|end_header_id|>

Five women talk about their experiences starting a business in the countryside. They all chose to move out of the city to start their own businesses.

**Christine Hogan** has a computer-aided design business. She used to work in London, but moved to the countryside to be closer to her family. She started her business at home and now has four full-time employees. She likes being able to work from home and can even work in the evenings if she wants to.

**Maggy Sasanow** is a designer who makes greetings cards. She used to work in an art museum, but moved to the countryside after she got married. She started her own business and sells her cards to museums. She works from home, but sometimes finds it hard to switch off from work.

**Delia Turner** makes curtains. She started her business eight years ago and it was very successful. She had to lay off her employees when the economy declined, but is now back to working from home with the help of her husband and a few part-time workers.

**Tessa Strickland** runs a children's book publishing business. She moved to the countryside for financial reasons and to be closer to nature. She enjoys being able to work at her own pace and takes calls from all over the world.

**Meg Rivers** makes cakes and sells them online and in her shop. She started her business at home and now employs six people. She had to work hard to get her business off the ground, but is now very successful.

All of these women have chosen to start their own businesses in the countryside. They enjoy the freedom and flexibility that comes with working for themselves, and are proud of what they have achieved.<|eot_id|>

The Watkins family is very special because they are all musicians. The father, John, makes instruments, and his sons, Paul and Huw, are composers and prize-winning musicians.

John now makes violins full-time and sells them to famous musicians. Paul and Huw started playing music when they were young. Paul learned to play the piano first, but then he switched to the cello. Huw started with the piano too, but he didn't like it as much as the cello.

Both brothers were encouraged to play music by their parents. Paul won a big competition on the cello and became the principal cellist of the BBC Symphony Orchestra. He played his father's cello for a long time, but now he plays a new cello on loan from the Royal Academy of Music.

Paul and Huw are both doing well in their music careers. Paul will be playing on TV soon, and Huw's string quartet will be performed at a concert in London. Their parents will have to work hard to keep track of all their sons' music activities.

Here is the simplified text for a B1 learner:

'MUSIC SCHOOLS FOR TALENTED CHILDREN

What to do if your child is very good at music? It's not always easy to help them develop their talent. Some parents might not notice their child's gift until they start behaving badly because they're not getting the help they need. Most schools are good at helping children who are good at other subjects, but music schools are special because they understand children who are very good at music.

There are five music schools in Britain that are perfect for children who are between 7 and 18 years old. These schools provide a special environment where children can learn and practice music with professional musicians. They spend most of their day doing music activities like playing instruments, singing, and practicing with a teacher. They also have some time for regular school subjects like English, maths, and science.

The schools are small and have a high number of teachers for each student. Most students live at the school, which means they are with other students who like music just like them. This can be a great way to make friends and learn together.

There are some disadvantages to these schools. They are expensive, with fees ranging from £12,000 to £17,000 per year. However, the schools try to help parents who can't afford the fees. Some parents might not want their children to live away from home at such a young age. The directors of the schools think it's better to wait until children are a bit older before sending them to a music school.

It's also important to consider the pressure of being a music student. Some children might feel stressed or unhappy if they're not doing well. The schools keep an eye on each student and offer help if needed. Some former students like the music schools, but others think it's too focused on music and not enough on other subjects. If your child is very good at music and also good at other subjects, they might do well at a normal school with a good music department or by taking music lessons outside of school.'

Are you trying to get your writing published? Margaret Stubbs is here to help. Many people write to us asking, "Where can I send my story?" First, you need to research the market and learn about publishers. You also need to improve your writing skills. To do this, you should read a lot of different types of writing. Visit your local library and bookstores to find out what kinds of writing publishers are looking for. Keep in mind that publishers' preferences change over time, so you need to stay up-to-date.

If you're not sure what kind of writing you want to do, start by reading different types of stories and magazines. For example, if you like writing love stories, find out which magazines publish them and read some recent issues. This will help you understand what kind of stories they like and who their readers are.

Don't send your writing to publishers too early. Most new writers make the same mistake. They send their work out too soon, before it's good enough. Instead, write more stories and improve them. Don't be discouraged if you get rejected. Every successful writer has been rejected many times. Keep writing and learning, and you will get better.

To improve your writing, you can take a creative writing course or join a local writers' group. This will help you meet other writers and get ideas and confidence. Remember, to be a good writer, you need to keep writing every day.<|eot_id|>

Here is the simplified text for a B1 learner:

I was waiting for my train at Baltimore railway station on a cold winter day. There were many people waiting, more than I expected. The station was usually clean and quiet, but today it was noisy and crowded. I saw an old man walking around, talking to strangers. He was well-dressed and seemed important. He asked a woman if she was going to Philadelphia, but she said she was going to New York. He then asked an old lady, but she said she was going to Wilmington. I noticed him because he seemed stressed and was asking a lot of people if they were going to Philadelphia.

I was going to Philadelphia myself, but he didn't ask me. I thought maybe he didn't think I was reliable. He walked away and asked another woman if she was going to Philadelphia. She said yes, and he asked her for a favor. He told her that his daughter was going to fly to Philadelphia and had forgotten her passport. He had already sent his daughter to the station and was now looking for someone to bring the passport to her. The woman was kind and said she would help.

I didn't think this story sounded right. Why didn't he go himself to get the passport? The woman asked him why he couldn't leave his wife alone, and he said she was in a wheelchair. I thought this was a weak excuse. I also noticed that he was holding a padded envelope, which seemed suspicious. I thought the woman should be careful.

Note: I removed some details that are not essential to the story, and rephrased some sentences to make them simpler and easier to understand. I also removed some idiomatic expressions and colloquial language that might be difficult for a B1 learner to understand.<|eot_id|>

Ice skating has a long history. People used animal bone skates thousands of years ago. In Scandinavia, skating was important for the upper class. To start ice skating, you need to be balanced and controlled. Your body position is important. Keep your legs slightly bent and your knees slightly bent too. This will help you stay balanced. It's also important to relax while skating. If you're tense, you might fall.

To get started, stand with your heels almost touching and your feet pointing outwards. Move your back foot forward while making a small movement with your other foot. This might seem easy, but it takes practice to get it right.

Even experienced skaters fall sometimes. To fall safely, try to relax and roll with the fall. To get up, get into a kneeling position and then stand up.

There are different types of ice skating, such as figure skating, free skating, and speed skating. To start, it's best to learn figure skating and then move on to elementary free skating. Most ice rinks offer lessons and guidance to help you learn.

To improve your skating, practice regularly and do exercises to loosen up your legs, back, and shoulders. This will help you stay relaxed and flexible. Skating is a great way to improve your balance, coordination, and overall health.

When I was young, I would write notes to my mother. My mother always wanted me to write thank-you letters for presents. It didn't matter if they were short or messy, as long as they were letters.

When I moved to London to study medicine, I would write to my mother once a week. Sometimes my father would write too, and his letters were always fun to read. Most of the letters from home were about everyday things that happened to my parents and their friends. We would also talk on the phone, but I remember the letters more.

I've also had letters from my boyfriends. When I was young, I seemed to meet people who had to be away for work or study, so we would stay in touch by writing. I found that I could express myself better in writing than talking.

I love getting letters with birthday or Christmas cards. A note is nice, but it's even better to get a year's worth of news! And it's extra special if it's a letter from someone in another country, with a special stamp.

I have penfriends in Sri Lanka, Australia, and Canada. If I hadn't met them in different places, I wouldn't be able to write to them. It's important to keep writing letters because it helps us stay in touch and learn more about each other. My children are also learning to write letters, just like I did. I'm glad that they are carrying on the tradition."

Shopping with children can be very difficult for some mothers. They always want to buy everything they see. If it's not the latest cereal, it's a Disney video or a comic. The mother feels guilty when she says no to her children's requests because she doesn't want to buy them unhealthy food. But she also feels bad when she says yes because she knows it's not good for them. She tries to avoid taking them shopping, but then she worries that she's not letting them make their own choices.

Research shows that children ask for something to buy every two minutes when they're shopping with their parents. A lot of money is spent advertising to children, especially on TV. Children often don't understand why their parents can't buy them everything they want. They don't understand that the advertisements are trying to persuade them to buy things.

Susan Dibb from the National Food Alliance says that parents are concerned about what their children eat, but they may not always know what is healthy. She thinks it's good that parents and children talk about food, but it's hard for parents to compete with advertisements. The Independent Television Commission says that advertisers can't tell children to ask their parents to buy something, but the goal of advertising is to make people want to buy something.

Some parents feel stressed when they're shopping with their children because they have to decide what to buy and what not to buy. One mother says that she talks to her children about different products and reads the labels with them. She's happy that they don't ask for things she doesn't want to buy anymore.

Parents also admit that they're not always consistent when it comes to buying things for their children. They might say no to their child's request for sweets because it's not good for them, but then they buy unhealthy food for themselves. Supermarkets could make shopping easier for parents by moving sweets to a different part of the store or providing a play area for children. This might make parents want to shop there more often.<|eot_id|>

Walls could only be built straight up and down, unlike cliffs, which have overhangs and angled rocks. Climbers would eventually get bored with the same old walls, even if they thought of every possible combination of holds.

In 1985, a Frenchman named Francois Savigny invented a material that could be molded into shapes like those found on cliffs. These shapes could be attached to any existing wall and removed when climbers got bored. French manufacturers also experimented with panels on steel frames. Steel frames could be set up anywhere and were lighter than concrete, making it possible to create overhanging walls without major construction work. This system allowed climbers to have endless new holds to try."<|eot_id|>

They have to find ways to deal with the stress of trying out for parts and the possibility of being rejected.

It's hard to talk about your chances of getting a part. Actors try to protect themselves from the stress and rejection. Nobody likes being rejected. Do you know that the average height of people in Europe is increasing by one centimetre every decade? This means that more and more people are becoming taller. Instead, we're going back to what our ancestors were like 40,000 years ago. 

For most of human history, our ancestors ate a variety of foods, including fruits, berries, and animals. This diet was very healthy and made them strong and tall. However, about 9,000 years ago, people started farming and this had a negative impact on their health. They began to eat fewer foods and became shorter and less healthy. 

In some places, like the US, Europe, and Japan, people are now eating a more balanced diet and their average height is increasing. This is good news, but it also means that we need to make sure our buildings and clothes are designed for taller people. 

But here's a surprise: scientists think that, as a species, humans are actually getting smaller. This is because our ancestors were bigger and rounder during the last ice age, which made them better at keeping warm. Since the climate warmed up, we've become thinner and smaller. And as the planet continues to warm up, we might even get smaller again. This means that the growth of humans could be stopped by global warming.<|eot_id|>

One idea is for the PCC to take the initiative and stop these shameful attacks. This could lead to many newspapers being punished. This would be reported by other newspapers and on TV and radio. The public would not support it, and editors would have to stop publishing these pictures. Photographers would also be affected, as they would no longer be able to make a living taking pictures of celebrities. However, there are many problems with this idea. How would the PCC decide whether to investigate a case? Should it ask the person involved to make a complaint? And what if they refuse? Celebrities and royalty might expect the PCC to investigate any story about them, and then be upset if it doesn't. The PCC's role is too big. How could it monitor all British newspapers, national and local? There is also the problem of embarrassment. Even if someone's privacy has been invaded, they might not want the added embarrassment of an investigation. Many people just want to move on with their lives. A few might have other reasons for staying quiet. They might have a worse story that they have kept secret, and they know that if they complain, this story could become public too. Even the PCC might become the enemy. A British comedian was also a victim of the press when his honeymoon was secretly photographed. He didn't complain then, and not even when his family was again photographed on holiday. He was afraid that the newspaper would run the pictures again with a new story about his anger. D. Barbara

E. Kim

Here is the simplified text for a B1 learner:

What is money? Money is like a unit of measurement, just like a gram or a kilometre. But instead of measuring weight or distance, money is used to buy things. A five-pound note can buy a book, a big bag of sweets, or two cinema tickets. But the note itself is just a piece of paper that doesn't cost much to make.

A long time ago, people didn't have money like we do today. There were no banks or shops. Instead, people would trade things with each other. For example, a farmer might exchange some corn for honey from a beekeeper. This was a direct exchange between two people, each giving something the other wanted.

As time went on, societies started to create their own special money, so people could trade more easily. Over time, these different types of money joined together, and that's why we use national currencies today.<|eot_id|>

We walked around the rock and watched the sunset. From Alice Springs, there are two trains a week going south, so many people break their journey here. The view after Alice Springs isn't exciting - just flat land with cows. But on the third day, we reached the hills near the Southern Ocean. My journey was over, and although the train wasn't perfect, it showed me some amazing sights in Australia.

Every year, many people climb Ben Nevis, a big mountain in Scotland. It's a challenging climb because of the cold weather. I, Keith Hewitt, climbed Ben Nevis for the first time in February. We went up the north face of the mountain to Tower Ridge. It's a long climb - 600 meters up. We planned to camp for three days halfway up the mountain. We took special equipment, like tents, sleeping bags, and special spikes for our boots, because the snow is very hard and slippery.

Even though some of my friends were very experienced climbers, we took all the necessary safety gear, including lights and extra clothes. The weather forecast was good, but we were still a bit nervous. Ben Nevis is always a challenge in winter.

The climb was hard, and my legs felt heavy. I had to stop often to rest. My friends would wait for me to catch up, and then we would continue climbing. I learned that I need to train more before climbing in the future.

After 200 meters, we reached the start of Tower Ridge. It's a narrow path, only 1.5 meters wide, and the mountain drops away on both sides. We had to be careful and focus on every step. After seven hours of climbing, we reached the top. On a clear day, you can see the sea and the island of Skye, which is 48 kilometers away. But we weren't lucky that day, as a mist came down.

Getting down from the top was just as challenging as going up. We had to use a map to make sure we didn't take a wrong turn and end up on a slope that was too dangerous to climb down in winter. I was glad we took turns doing this job. It wasn't until I was safe in my tent that I could say I really enjoyed the experience. At least I made it to the top!<|eot_id|>

THE ICEHOTEL

For a long time, people visited the Arctic in the summer to see the midnight sun. But in the winter, the few people who lived there had the snow and ice all to themselves. Then, people thought, "Why not use the cold winter to create something special?"

In 1990, a French artist named Jannot Derit was invited to create an exhibition in a special snow building in the town of Jukkasjarvi. The building was called Arctic Hall, and many people came to visit. One night, some guests had the idea to sleep in Arctic Hall. They liked it so much that they thought, "Why not build a whole hotel made of ice?"

Now, every year, a team of people from all over the world come to Jukkasjarvi to build the hotel. They start in December and finish in January. The hotel is built outside, so the weather can affect the building process. When it gets warmer in the spring, the hotel melts.

Inside the hotel, it's always around -5°C to -8°C, even when it's very cold outside. You can borrow warm clothes like overalls, hats, and gloves when you stay at the hotel. It's also a good idea to bring your own warm clothes and thick socks. You can buy these things on the ICEHOTEL website when you book your visit.

The hotel is in a village called Jukkasjarvi, near the Arctic Circle. It's close to the airport and train station in Kiruna. You can take a bus from the airport or train station to the hotel.

Day 6: We will drive to Sao Joao da Pesqueira for a stunning view of the Douro valley. We will return to the ship for lunch and then take a train ride through the countryside to Regua, where the Lady Ivy May will be waiting for us.

Day 7: We will visit Vila Real and then return to the ship for lunch and continue our journey down the river to Oporto.

Day 8: We will arrive in Oporto in the morning, with plenty of time to explore and do some last-minute shopping before our flight back to London Heathrow.'

Here is the simplified text for a B1 learner:

THE IDITAROD TRAIL - A LONG WINTER JOURNEY

A long time ago, people found gold in Alaska, a state in the USA. Many people went there to look for gold. A town called Iditarod grew quickly and became the biggest city in Alaska. But in the winter, it was hard to get supplies to the town because the rivers and ocean were frozen. So, in 1910, a special path was built for dogs to pull sleds. They carried mail, food, and clothes to the gold miners. This path was called the Iditarod Trail.

It took the dogs about three weeks to travel across Alaska. They stopped at special places where the drivers could rest and eat. The trail was used every winter until airplanes became popular. But in 1925, the dogs had one last big job. A disease called diphtheria was spreading in Nome, a city in Alaska. The medicine to cure the disease was in Anchorage, but it was too far away. The pilots were not sure if they could fly in the cold weather. So, the medicine was sent by dog sled instead.

Twenty teams of dogs worked together to make the journey. The first part was done by a man named Leonhard Seppala and his dog Togo. They had to find their way in the snow. Then, Gunnar Kaasen and his dog Saito finished the journey. One of the dogs, Balto, was very brave and saved the team from falling into the water. The diphtheria was stopped, and Balto became a hero.

Now, every year, a dog sled race is held from Anchorage to Nome, following the same path as that famous journey in 1925. It's called the Iditarod and is known as 'The Last Great Race on Earth'.<|eot_id|>

Gareth Ellis is 13 years old. He is the youngest son of Alan, an engineer, and Kath, a nursery teacher. Gareth's brothers work in banking and computers, but Gareth wants to be a clown. When Alan lost his job, he and Kath decided to work with the circus full-time. They both got jobs and Gareth started training to be a clown. He calls himself Bippo. They travel with the circus in the summer and go home in the winter. Gareth's brothers take care of the house while they're away.

It wasn't easy for them to make this change. They had to think about a lot of things and organize many things. They only had a small car and a small caravan to sleep in, and they had to leave their big house behind. The only thing Gareth missed was taking long, hot baths.

Some people ask about Gareth's education. But he doesn't miss school because there is always someone to teach him wherever they go. He follows the same books as his classmates and has a computer. He hasn't fallen behind his friends.

What about the future? 'It was a difficult decision,' says Kath, 'but this is the best way for Gareth to learn about being a clown. We're happy and enjoying it.' And Gareth? 'I want to be the main clown in a circus one day,' he says, 'perhaps in Bippo's circus.'<|eot_id|>

Here is the simplified text:

**Antarctica Sightseeing Flights**

Welcome to our website! Here's what you need to know before booking a flight.

We take tourists on a special flight from Sydney, Australia, to Antarctica and back. The flight is about 12 hours long. We usually see sea ice and icebergs after four hours, and then spend four hours flying over Antarctica. The rest of the time, we fly back to Sydney.

During the flight, experts who have lived on Antarctic research stations will talk to us about the environment and history. You can also ask them questions. There's a special camera that shows you what the pilot sees, from take-off to landing.

**Seating**

Everyone gets two boarding passes. Halfway through the flight, you'll move to the seat on your second pass. Business and first class passengers will have a window seat for half the flight and a next-to-window seat for the other half. Economy passengers will have a window seat or a seat next to a window seat for half the flight, and an end-of-row seat for the other half.

**Getting Around**

While we're over Antarctica, you can get up and walk around the plane to see the sights from different sides. The pilot flies in special patterns to make sure everyone can see everything.

**Weather**

We have 17 different flight plans. The captain looks at the weather forecast and chooses the best route for good views.

**Wildlife**

Unfortunately, we can't see penguins and other wildlife because they live at sea level, below the plane. We don't land on Antarctica because of environmental reasons. If you want to see Antarctic wildlife, you need to join a boat tour.

**Photography**

You're welcome to take photos! We even have some fun photo opportunities where you can try on Antarctic clothes.<|eot_id|>

|end_header_id|>

Fog can suddenly appear over a hill, and ice can be hiding under the snow, waiting to send you off the road. The car in front of you might slide across the road. To drive safely on icy roads, remember two important rules. First, drive smoothly. Sudden movements can make your car hard to control. Imagine you're driving with a cup of hot coffee next to you - drive slowly so you don't spill it. Second, be prepared for anything that might happen. On icy roads, you need to look further ahead than usual. Test how long it takes to stop by gently pressing the brakes. Remember, you might be driving faster than you think. Craigie Aitchison was a Scottish painter. He went to London to study law, but instead, he went to art school. He didn't like the traditional drawing classes, but he kept painting. When he was in his late twenties, the Italian government gave him money to study art. He became interested in old Italian artists and their use of light and color. He loved the green and brown colors of the Italian fields and the clear light, and he wanted to put this in his paintings. To do this, he painted thin layers of color on top of each other, from light to dark. He says it's a secret because he's not sure what the result will be.

Aitchison is a talented artist, but he makes it sound easy. He says anyone can buy the colors he uses. He just notices what happens when he puts the colors next to each other. Unlike some artists, Aitchison doesn't make drawings before he starts painting. He thinks if he does, he might get bored and not finish the painting. Instead, he changes his paintings many times before they're finished. That's why he likes painting people who don't ask to see their pictures while he's working on them. If they get worried and want to look, he can't focus.

Aitchison doesn't feel connected to the Scottish painting scene, and he doesn't follow any particular style. He just paints the way he can. Despite this, his work still inspires young British painters.<|eot_id|>

I like to exercise. Before I had an accident, I went to the gym for two and a half hours, five days a week. Now, I do 150 sit-ups every day because I can't go to the gym as much.

I don't drink alcohol or smoke. I try to eat well and drink a lot of water. I should drink eight glasses a day, but I don't always remember to do that.

It's important to have a balance in life. I love my job, but I also like doing other things in my free time, like listening to music or watching TV. Sometimes, it's good to do nothing.
